documentation.result: A geometry corresponding to the cleaning of the operand (geometry, agent, point)
documentation.comment: The cleaning corresponds to a buffer with a distance of 0.0

example.code: cleaning(self) -> returns the geometry resulting from the cleaning of the geometry of the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: A list of agents covered by the operand (casted as a geometry).

example.code: agents_inside(self) -> return the agents that are covered by the shape of the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: the mean of all the elements of the operand
documentation.comment: the elements of the operand are summed (see sum for more details about the sum of container elements ) and then the sum value is divided by the number of elements.

case.item: if the container contains points, the result will be a point

documentation.result: A value from a random variable following a binomial distribution. The operand {n,p} represents the number of experiments n and the success probability p.
documentation.comment: The binomial distribution is the discrete probability distribution of the number of successes in a sequence of n independent yes/no experiments, each of which yields success with probability p, cf. Binomial distribution on Wikipedia.

documentation.result: The two part of the left-operand lines split at the given right-operand point

case.item: if the left-operand is a point or a polygon, returns an empty list

documentation.result: the product of all the elements of the operand
documentation.comment: the mul operator behavior depends on the nature of the operand

case.item: if it is a list of int or float: mul returns the product of all the elements
if it is a list of points: mul returns the product of all points as a point (each coordinate is the product of the corresponding coordinate of each element)
if it is a list of other types: mul transforms all elements into float and multiplies them
if it is a map, mul returns the product of the value of all elements
if it is a file, mul returns the product of the content of the file (that is also a container)
if it is a graph, mul returns the product of the list of the elements of the graph (that can be the list of edges or vertexes depending on the graph)
if it is a matrix of int, float or object, mul returns the product of all the numerical elements (thus all elements for integer and float matrices)
if it is a matrix of geometry, mul returns the product of the list of the geometries

documentation.result: A geometry corresponding to the operand geometry (geometry, agent, point) without its holes

example.code: solid(self) -> returns the geometry corresponding to the geometry of the agent applying the operator without its holes.

documentation.result: A list of left-operand number of points located at a the right-operand distance to the agent location.

example.code: 3 points_at(20.0) -> returns [pt1, pt2, pt3] with pt1, pt2 and pt3 located at a distance of 20.0 to the agent location

documentation.result: A agent, the closest to the operand (casted as a geometry).
documentation.comment: the distance is computed in the topology of the calling agent (the agent in which this operator is used), with the distance algorithm specific to the topology.

example.code: agent_closest_to(self) -> return the closest agent to the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: A triangle geometry which side size is given by the operand.
documentation.comment: the centre of the triangle is by default the location of the current agent in which has been called this operator.

case.item: returns nil if the operand is nil.

example.code: triangle(5) -> returns a geometry as a triangle with side_size = 5.

documentation.result: A polygon geometry from the given list of points.

case.item: if the operand is nil, returns the point geometry {0,0}
if the operand is composed of a single point, returns a point geometry
if the operand is composed of 2 points, returns a polyline geometry.

example.code: polygon([{0,0}, {0,10}, {10,10}, {10,0}]) -> returns a polygon geometry composed of the 4 points.

documentation.result: A distance between a list of geometries (geometries, agents, points) considering a topology.

example.code: my_topology distance_between [ag1, ag2, ag3] -> the distance between ag1, ag2 and ag3 considering the topology my_topology

documentation.result: the operand elements in the reversed order in a copy of the operand.
documentation.comment: the reverse operator behavior depends on the nature of the operand

case.item: if it is a list, reverse returns a copy of the operand list with elements in the reversed order
if it is a map, reverse returns a copy of the operand map with each pair in the reversed order (i.e. all keys become values and values become keys)
if it is a file, reverse returns a copy of the file with a reversed content
if it is a population, reverse returns a copy of the population with elements in the reversed order
if it is a graph, reverse returns a copy of the graph (with all edges and vertexes), with all of the edges reversed
if it is a matrix, reverse returns a new matrix containing the transpose of the operand.
if it is a string, reverse returns a new string with caracters in the reversed order

documentation.result: the standard deviation on the elements of the operand. See Standard_deviation for more details.
documentation.comment: The operator casts all the numerical element of the list into float. The elements that are not numerical are discarded.

documentation.result: A list of geometries resulting after cutting the lines at their intersections.
true or false given the probability represented by the operand

case.item: flip 0 always returns false, flip 1 true

documentation.result: A geometry corresponding to the convex hull of the operand.

example.code: convex_hull(self) -> returns the convex hull of the geometry of the agent applying the operator

documentation.result: the geometric mean of the elements of the operand. See Geometric_mean for more details.
documentation.comment: The operator casts all the numerical element of the list into float. The elements that are not numerical are discarded.

documentation.result: a random element from the containera random element from the list
documentation.comment: the one_of operator behavior depends on the nature of the operand

case.item: if the operand is empty, one_of returns nil
if it is a list or a matrix, one_of returns one of the elements of the list or of the matrix
if it is a map, one_of returns one of the values of the map
if it is a graph, one_of returns one of the nodes of the graph
if it is a file, one_of returns one of the elements of the content of the file (that is also a container)
if it is a population, one_of returns one of the agents of the population
if the list is empty, returns nil

If the operand is a species, the operand is casted to a list before the expression is evaluated. Therefore, if foo is the name of a species, any(foo) will return a random agent from this species (see list)

example.code: // The species bug has previously been defined
one_of (bug) -> bug3 // The species `bug` has previously be defined

documentation.result: A list of agents among the left-operand list, covered by the operand (casted as a geometry).

case.item: if the left-operand is a species, return agents of the specified species (slightly more efficient than using list(species1), for instance).

example.code: [ag1, ag2, ag3] inside(self) -> return the agents among ag1, ag2 and ag3 that are covered by the shape of the agent applying the operator.
species1 inside(self) -> return the agents of species species1 that are covered by the shape of the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: A geometry resulting from the application of a rotation and a translation (rigth-operand : point {angle(degree), distance} of the left-hand operand (geometry, agent, point)

example.code: self transformed_by {45, 20} -> returns the geometry resulting from 45� rotation and 10m translation of the geometry of the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: A boolean, equal to true if the left-geometry (or agent/point) intersects the right-geometry (or agent/point).

case.item: if one of the operand is null, returns false.

documentation.result: A list of agent groups clustered by distance (considering the agent envelop) considering a distance min between two groups.
documentation.comment: use of hierarchical clustering with Minimum for linkage criterion between two groups of agents.

example.code: [ag1, ag2, ag3, ag4, ag5] simpleClusteringByDistance 20.0 -> for example, can return [[ag1, ag3], [ag2], [ag4, ag5]]

documentation.result: true if the operand is empty, false otherwise.
documentation.comment: the empty operator behavior depends on the nature of the operand

case.item: if it is a list, empty returns true if there is no element in the list, and false otherwise
if it is a map, empty returns true if the map contains no key-value mappings, and false otherwise
if it is a file, empty returns true if the content of the file (that is also a container) is empty, and false otherwise
if it is a population, empty returns true if there is no agent in the population, and false otherwise
if it is a graph, empty returns true if it contains no vertex and no edge, and false otherwise
if it is a matrix of int, float or object, it will return true if all elements are respectively 0, 0.0 or null, and false otherwise
if it is a matrix of geometry, it will return true if the matrix contains no cell, and false otherwise
if it is a string, empty returns true if the string does not contain any character, and false otherwise

documentation.result: A rectangle geometry which side sizes are given by the operands.
documentation.comment: the centre of the rectangle is by default the location of the current agent in which has been called this operator.

case.item: returns nil if the operand is nil.

example.code: rectangle({10, 5}) -> returns a geometry as a rectangle with width = 10 and heigh = 5.

documentation.result: the harmonic mean of the elements of the operand. See Harmonic_mean for more details.
documentation.comment: The operator casts all the numerical element of the list into float. The elements that are not numerical are discarded.

documentation.result: A point inside (or touching) the operand-geometry.

example.code: any_location_in(square(5)) -> a point of the square, for example : {3,4.6}.

documentation.result: A polyline geometry from the given list of points.

case.item: if the operand is nil, returns the point geometry {0,0}
if the operand is composed of a single point, returns a point geometry.

example.code: polyline([{0,0}, {0,10}, {10,10}, {10,0}]) -> returns a polyline geometry composed of the 4 points.

documentation.result: A value from a random variable following a Poisson distribution (with the positive expected number of occurence lambda as operand).
documentation.comment: The Poisson distribution is a discrete probability distribution that expresses the probability of a given number of events occurring in a fixed interval of time and/or space if these events occur with a known average rate and independently of the time since the last event, cf. Poisson distribution on Wikipedia.

documentation.result: A matrix of square geometries (grid with 4-neighbourhood) with dimension given by the rigth-hand operand ({nb_cols, nb_lines}) corresponding to the square tessellation of the left-hand operand geometry (geometry, agent)

example.code: self as_grid {10, 5} -> returns matrix of square geometries (grid with 4-neighbourhood) with 10 columns and 5 lines corresponding to the square tessellation of the geometry of the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: the element at the right operand index of the container
documentation.comment: The first element of the container is located at the index 0. In addition, if the user tries to get the element at an index higher or equals than the length of the container, he will get an IndexOutOfBoundException.The at operator behavior depends on the nature of the operand

case.item: if it is a list or a matrix, at returns the element at the index specified by the right operand
if it is a map, at returns the value corresponding the right operand as key. If the right operand is not a key of the map, at returns nil
if it is a file, at returns the element of the file content at the index specified by the right operand
if it is a population, at returns the agent at the index specified by the right operand
if it is a graph, if the right operand is a node, at returns the in and out edges corresponding to that node; if it is an edge, at returns the pair node_out::node_in.

documentation.result: A boolean, equal to true if the left-geometry (or agent/point) touches the right-geometry (or agent/point).
documentation.comment: returns true when the left-operand only touches the right-operand. When one geometry covers partially (or fully) the other one, it returns false.

case.item: if one of the operand is null, returns false.

documentation.result: A list of two closest points between the two geometries.

example.code: geom1 closest_points_with(geom2) -> [pt1, pt2] with pt1 the closest point of geom1 to geom2 and pt1 the closest point of geom2 to geom1

documentation.result: A value from a normally distributed random variable with expected value (mean) and variance (standardDeviation). The probability density function of such a variable is a Gaussian.

case.item: when the operand is a point, it is read as {mean, standardDeviation}
when standardDeviation value is 0.0, it always returns the mean value

documentation.result: the median of all the elements of the operand.
documentation.comment: The operator casts all the numerical element of the list into float. The elements that are not numerical are discarded.

documentation.result: a random integer in the interval [0, operand]
documentation.comment: to obtain a probability between 0 and 1, use the expression (rnd n) / n, where n is used to indicate the precision

case.item: if the operand is a float, it is casted to an int before being evaluated
if the operand is a point, returns a point with two random integers in the interval [0, operand]

example.code: rnd (1000) / 1000 -> a float between 0 and 1 with a precision of 0.001
rnd ({2.5,3}) -> {x,y} with x in [0,2] and y in [0,3]

documentation.result: A list of agents overlapping the operand (casted as a geometry).

example.code: agents_overlapping(self) -> return the agents that overlap the shape of the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: A path between two geometries (geometries, agents or points) considering the topology of the agent applying the operator.

example.code: ag1 path_to ag2 -> the path between ag1 and ag2 considering the topology of the agent applying the operator

documentation.result: A geometry resulting from the intersection between the two geometries

case.item: returns false if the right-operand is nil

documentation.result: A list of agent groups clustered by distance considering a distance min between two groups.
documentation.comment: use of hierarchical clustering with Minimum for linkage criterion between two groups of agents.

example.code: [ag1, ag2, ag3, ag4, ag5] simpleClusteringByDistance 20.0 -> for example, can return [[ag1, ag3], [ag2], [ag4, ag5]]

documentation.result: A boolean, equal to true if the left-geometry (or agent/point) partially overlaps the right-geometry (or agent/point).
documentation.comment: if one geometry operand fully covers the other geometry operand, returns false (contrarily to the overlaps operator).

case.item: if one of the operand is null, returns false.

documentation.result: the variance of the elements of the operand. See Variance for more details.
documentation.comment: The operator casts all the numerical element of the list into float. The elements that are not numerical are discarded.

documentation.result: A boolean, equal to true if the left-geometry (or agent/point) is disjoints from the right-geometry (or agent/point).

case.item: if one of the operand is null, returns true.
if one operand is a point, returns false if the point is included in the geometry.

documentation.result: the deviation from the mean of all the elements of the operand. See Mean_deviation for more details.
documentation.comment: The operator casts all the numerical element of the list into float. The elements that are not numerical are discarded.

documentation.result: A list of geometries (triangles) corresponding to the Delaunay triangulation of the operand geometry (geometry, agent, point)

example.code: triangulate(self) -> returns the list of geometries (triangles) corresponding to the Delaunay triangulation of the geometry of the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: the maximum element found in the operand
documentation.comment: the max operator behavior depends on the nature of the operand

case.item: if it is a list of int of float, max returns the maximum of all the elements

if it is a list of points: max returns the maximum of all points as a point (i.e. the point with the greatest coordinate on the x-axis, in case of equality the point with the greatest coordinate on the y-axis is chosen. If all the points are equal, the first one is returned. )
if it is a list of other type: max transforms all elements into float and returns the maximum of them
if it is a map, max returns the maximum among the list of all elements value
if it is a file, max returns the maximum of the content of the file (that is also a container)
if it is a graph, max returns the maximum of the list of the elements of the graph (that can be the list of edges or vertexes depending on the graph)
if it is a matrix of int, float or object, max returns the maximum of all the numerical elements (thus all elements for integer and float matrices)
if it is a matrix of geometry, max returns the maximum of the list of the geometries

documentation.result: A link between the 2 elements of the pair.
documentation.comment: The geometry of the link is the intersection of the two geometries when they intersect, and a line between their centroids when they do not.

case.item: if the operand is nil, link returns a point {0,0}
if one of the elements of the pair is a list of geometries or a species, link will consider the union of the geometries or of the geometry of each agent of the species

example.code: link (geom1::geom2) -> returns a link geometry between geom1 and geom2.

documentation.result: the sum of all the elements of the operand
documentation.comment: the sum operator behavior depends on the nature of the operand

case.item: if it is a list of int or float: sum returns the sum of all the elements
if it is a list of points: sum returns the sum of all points as a point (each coordinate is the sum of the corresponding coordinate of each element)
if it is a list of other types: sum transforms all elements into float and sums them
if it is a map, sum returns the sum of the value of all elements
if it is a file, sum returns the sum of the content of the file (that is also a container)
if it is a graph, sum returns the sum of the list of the elements of the graph (that can be the list of edges or vertexes depending on the graph)
if it is a matrix of int, float or object, sum returns the sum of all the numerical elements (i.e. all elements for integer and float matrices)
if it is a matrix of geometry, sum returns the sum of the list of the geometries

documentation.result: The direction (in degree) between the two geometries (geometries, agents, points) considering the topology of the agent applying the operator.

example.code: ag1 towards ag2 -> the direction between ag1 and ag2 and ag3 considering the topology of the agent applying the operator

documentation.result: A list of geometries (polylines) corresponding to the skeleton of the operand geometry (geometry, agent)

example.code: skeletonize(self) -> returns the list of geometries corresponding to the skeleton of the geometry of the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: A list of agents among the left-operand list that are located at a distance <= the right operand from the caller agent (in its topology)

case.item: If the left operand is a species, return agents of the specified species (slightly more efficient than using list(species1), for instance)

example.code: species1 at_distance 20 -> return the agents of species1 located at a distance <= 20 from the caller agent.
[ag1, ag2, ag3] at_distance 20 -> return the agents of the list located at a distance <= 20 from the caller agent (in the same order).

documentation.result: A matrix of square geometries (grid with 8-neighbourhood) with dimension given by the rigth-hand operand ({nb_cols, nb_lines}) corresponding to the square tessellation of the left-hand operand geometry (geometry, agent)

example.code: self as_grid {10, 5} -> returns a matrix of square geometries (grid with 8-neighbourhood) with 10 columns and 5 lines corresponding to the square tessellation of the geometry of the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: A geometry resulting from the difference between a buffer around the right-operand casted in geometry at a distance left-operand (right-operand buffer left-operand) and the right-operand casted as geometry.

case.item: returns a circle geometry of radius right-operand if the left-operand is nil

example.code: 10 around circle(5) -> returns a the ring geometry between 5 and 10.

documentation.result: An agent among the left-operand list, the closest to the operand (casted as a geometry).
documentation.comment: the distance is computed in the topology of the calling agent (the agent in which this operator is used), with the distance algorithm specific to the topology.

case.item: if the left-operand is a species, return an agent of the specified species.

example.code: [ag1, ag2, ag3] closest_to(self) -> return the closest agent among ag1, ag2 and ag3 to the agent applying the operator.
species1 closest_to(self) -> return the closest agent of species species1 to the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: A path between a list of two geometries (geometries, agents or points) considering a topology.

example.code: my_topology path_between [ag1, ag2] -> A path between ag1 and ag2

documentation.result: the minimum element found in the operand.
documentation.comment: the min operator behavior depends on the nature of the operand

case.item: if it is a list of int or float: min returns the minimum of all the elements

if it is a list of points: min returns the minimum of all points as a point (i.e. the point with the smallest coordinate on the x-axis, in case of equality the point with the smallest coordinate on the y-axis is chosen. If all the points are equal, the first one is returned. )
if it is a list of other types: min transforms all elements into float and returns the minimum of them
if it is a map, min returns the minimum among the list of all elements value
if it is a file, min returns the minimum of the content of the file (that is also a container)
if it is a graph, min returns the minimum of the list of the elements of the graph (that can be the list of edges or vertexes depending on the graph)
if it is a matrix of int, float or object, min returns the minimum of all the numerical elements (thus all elements for integer and float matrices)
if it is a matrix of geometry, min returns the minimum of the list of the geometries

documentation.result: A boolean, equal to true if the left-geometry (or agent/point) crosses the right-geometry (or agent/point).

case.item: if one of the operand is null, returns false.
if one operand is a point, returns false.

documentation.result: A geometry resulting from the application of a rotation by the right-hand operand angle (degree) to the left-hand operand (geometry, agent, point)
documentation.comment: the right-hand operand can be a float or a int

example.code: self rotated_by 45 -> returns the geometry resulting from a 45 degres rotation to the geometry of the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: A distance between two geometries (geometries, agents or points) considering the topology of the agent applying the operator.

example.code: ag1 distance_to ag2 -> the distance between ag1 and ag2 considering the topology of the agent applying the operator

documentation.result: the farthest point of the left-operand to the left-point.

example.code: geom farthest_point_to(pt) -> the closest point of geom to pt

documentation.result: true, whether the container contains the right operand, false otherwise
documentation.comment: the contains operator behavior depends on the nature of the operand

case.item: if it is a list or a matrix, contains returns true if the list or matrix contains the right operand
if it is a map, contains returns true if the operand is a key of the map
if it is a file, contains returns true it the operand is contained in the file content
if it is a population, contains returns true if the operand is an agent of the population, false otherwise
if it is a graph, contains returns true if the operand is a node or an edge of the graph, false otherwise

documentation.result: A square geometry which side size is equal to the operand.
documentation.comment: the centre of the square is by default the location of the current agent in which has been called this operator.

case.item: returns nil if the operand is nil.

example.code: square(10) -> returns a geometry as a square of side size 10.

documentation.result: a list, containing all the agents located at a distance inferior or equal to 1 to the right-hand operand agent considering the left-hand operand topology.

case.item: a list, containing all the agents located at a distance inferior or equal to the right member (float) of the pair (right-hand operand) to the left member (agent, geometry or point) considering the left-hand operand topology.

example.code: topology(self) neighbours_of self -> returns all the agents located at a distance lower or equal to 1 to the agent applying the operator considering its topology.
topology(self) neighbours_of self::10-> returns all the agents located at a distance lower or equal to 10 to the agent applying the operator considering its topology.

documentation.result: A geometry corresponding to the simplification of the operand (geometry, agent, point) considering a tolerance distance.
documentation.comment: The algorithm used for the simplification is Douglas-Peucker

example.code: self simplification 0.1 -> returns the geometry resulting from the application of the Douglas-Peuker algorithm on the geometry of the agent applying the operator with a tolerance distance of 0.1.

documentation.result: A random value from a normally distributed random variable in the interval ]mean - standardDeviation; mean + standardDeviation[.

case.item: if the operand is a list, only the two first elements are taken into account as [mean, standardDeviation]
when truncated_gauss is called with a list of only one element mean, it will always return 0.0
when the operand is a point, it is read as {mean, standardDeviation}

documentation.result: A boolean, equal to true if the left-geometry (or agent/point) overlaps the right-geometry (or agent/point).

case.item: if one of the operand is null, returns false.
if one operand is a point, returns true if the point is included in the geometry

documentation.result: the number of elements contained in the operand
documentation.comment: the length operator behavior depends on the nature of the operand

case.item: if it is a list or a map, length returns the number of elements in the list or map
if it is a population, length returns number of agents of the population
if it is a graph, last returns the number of vertexes or of edges (depending on the way it was created)
if it is a matrix, length returns the number of cells
if it is a string, length returns the number of characters

if the left-hand operand is a geometry and the rigth-hand operand a float, returns a geometry corresponding to the left-hand operand (geometry, agent, point) scaled by the right-hand operand coefficient

example.code: shape * 2 -> returns a geometry corresponding to the geometry of the agent applying the operator scaled by a coefficient of 2

documentation.result: A geometry resulting from the tran of a translation to the right-hand operand point of the left-hand operand (geometry, agent, point)

example.code: self at_location {10, 20} -> returns the geometry resulting from a translation to the location {10, 20} of the geometry of the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: A circle geometry which radius is equal to the operand.
documentation.comment: the centre of the circle is by default the location of the current agent in which has been called this operator.

case.item: returns a point if the operand is lower or equal to 0.

example.code: circle(10) -> returns a geometry as a circle of radius 10.

documentation.result: the last element of the operand
documentation.comment: the last operator behavior depends on the nature of the operand

case.item: if it is a string, last returns a string composed of its last character, or an empty string if the operand is empty
if it is a list, last returns the last element of the list, or nil if the list is empty
if it is a map, last returns nil (the map do not keep track of the order of elements)
if it is a file, last returns the last element of the content of the file (that is also a container)
if it is a population, last returns the last agent of the population
if it is a graph, last returns the last element in the list of vertexes
if it is a matrix, last returns the element at {length-1,length-1} in the matrix
for a matrix of int or float, it will return 0 if the matrix is empty
for a matrix of object or geometry, it will return null if the matrix is empty

documentation.result: A geometry representing the part of the right operand visible from the point of view of the agent using the operator while considering the obstacles defined by the left operand

example.code: perception_geom masked_by obstacle_list -> returns the geometry representing the part of perception_geom visible from the agent position considering the list of obstacles obstacle_list.
perception_geom masked_by obstacle_species -> returns the geometry representing the part of perception_geom visible from the agent position considering the obstacles of species obstacle_species.

documentation.result: A geometry resulting from the application of a translation by the right-hand operand distance to the left-hand operand (geometry, agent, point)

example.code: self translated_by 45 -> returns the geometry resulting from a 10m translation to the geometry of the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: the first element of the operand
documentation.comment: the first operator behavior depends on the nature of the operand

case.item: if it is a list, first returns the first element of the list, or nil if the list is empty
if it is a map, first returns nil (the map do not keep track of the order of elements)
if it is a file, first returns the first element of the content of the file (that is also a container)
if it is a population, first returns the first agent of the population
if it is a graph, first returns the first element in the list of vertexes
if it is a matrix, first returns the element at {0,0} in the matrix
for a matrix of int or float, it will return 0 if the matrix is empty
for a matrix of object or geometry, it will return null if the matrix is empty
if it is a string, first returns a string composed of its first character

documentation.result: A list of agents a mong the left-operand list, overlapping the operand (casted as a geometry).

case.item: if the left-operand is a species, return agents of the specified species.

example.code: species1 overlapping(self) -> return the agents of species species1 that overlap the shape of the agent applying the operator.
[ag1, ag2, ag3] overlapping(self) -> return the agents among ag1, ag2 and ag3 that overlap the shape of the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: A cone geometry which min and max angles are given by the operands.
documentation.comment: the centre of the cone is by default the location of the current agent in which has been called this operator.

case.item: returns nil if the operand is nil.

example.code: cone({0, 45}) -> returns a geometry as a cone with min angle is 0 and max angle is 45.

documentation.result: A geometry resulting from the adding of a right-point (coordinate) to the right-geometry
a list, containing all the agents located at a distance inferior or equal to the right-hand operand to the left-hand operand (geometry, agent, point).
documentation.comment: The topology used to compute the neighbourhood is the one of the left-operand if this one is an agent; otherwise the one of the agent applying the operator.

example.code: (self neighbours_at (10)) -> returns all the agents located at a distance lower or equal to 10 to the agent applying the operator.

documentation.result: A list of agents situated at a distance <= the right argument.
documentation.comment: Equivalent to neighbours_at with a left-hand argument equal to 'self'

example.code: agents_at_distance(20) -> all the agents (excluding the caller) which distance to the caller is <= 20

documentation.result: The elements of the operand in random order.

case.item: if the operand is empty, returns an empty list (or string, matrix)

example.code: shuffle (bug) -> shuffle the list of all agents of the `bug` species

case.item: if the left-hand operand is a geometry and the rigth-hand operand a map (with [distance::float, quadrantSegments:: int (the number of line segments used to represent a quadrant of a circle), endCapStyle::int (1: (default) a semi-circle, 2: a straight line perpendicular to the end segment, 3: a half-square)]), returns a geometry corresponding to the left-hand operand (geometry, agent, point) enlarged considering the right-hand operand parameters

if the left-hand operand is a geometry and the rigth-hand operand a float, returns a geometry corresponding to the left-hand operand (geometry, agent, point) enlarged by the right-hand operand distance
if the right-operand is a point, a geometry or an agent, returns the geometry resulting from the union between both geometries

example.code: shape + [distance::5.0, quadrantSegments::4, endCapStyle:: 2] -> returns a geometry corresponding to the geometry of the agent applying the operator enlarged by a distance of 5, with 4 segments to represent a quadrant of a circle and a straight line perpendicular to the end segment
shape + 5 -> returns a geometry corresponding to the geometry of the agent applying the operator enlarged by a distance of 5
geom1 + geom2 -> a geometry corresponding to union between geom1 and geom2

documentation.result: The geometry resulting from the union of all geometries of agents of the operand-species

case.item: if the right-operand is a list of points, geometries or agents, returns the geometry resulting from the union all the geometries

example.code: union(species1) -> returns the geometry resulting from the union of all of the geometries of agents of species species1.
union([geom1, geom2, geom3]) -> a geometry corresponding to union between geom1, geom2 and geom3

case.item: if the right-operand is a species, returns the geometry resulting from the difference between the left-geometry and all of geometries all agents of the right-species
if the right-operand is a point, a geometry or an agent, returns the geometry resulting from the difference between both geometries

if the left-hand operand is a geometry and the rigth-hand operand a float, returns a geometry corresponding to the left-hand operand (geometry, agent, point) reduced by the right-hand operand distance
if the right-operand is a list of points, geometries or agents, returns the geometry resulting from the difference between the left-geometry and all of the right-geometries

example.code: geom1 - speciesA -> a geometry corresponding to geom1 - (the geometry of all agents of species speciesA)
geom1 - geom2 -> a geometry corresponding to difference between geom1 and geom2
shape - 5 -> returns a geometry corresponding to the geometry of the agent applying the operator reduced by a distance of 5
geom1 - [geom2, geom3, geom4] -> a geometry corresponding to geom1 - (geom2 + geom3 + geom4)

documentation.result: A direction (in degree) between a list of two geometries (geometries, agents, points) considering a topology.

example.code: my_topology direction_between [ag1, ag2] -> the direction between ag1 and ag2 considering the topology my_topology

var.doc: Represents the total time passed, in model time, since the beginning of the simulation
var.name: time

var.doc: The seed of the random number generator
var.name: seed

var.doc: Returns the current cycle of the simulation
var.name: cycle

var.doc: The random number generator to use for this simulation. Four different ones are at the disposal of the modeler: mersenne represents the default generator, based on the Mersenne-Twister algorithm. Very reliable; cellular is a cellular automaton based generator that should be a bit faster, but less reliable; xor is another choice. Much faster than the previous ones, but with short sequences; and java invokes the standard Java generator
var.name: rng

var.doc: Represents the value of the interval, in model time, between two simulation cycles
var.name: step

var.doc: Returns the current system time in milliseconds
var.name: machine_time

var.doc: Returns a string containing the duration, in milliseconds, of the previous simulation cycle
var.name: duration

var.doc: Returns a string containing the total duration, in milliseconds, of the simulation since it has been launched
var.name: total_duration

var.doc: Returns a string containing the average duration, in milliseconds, of a simulation cycle.
var.name: average_duration

var.doc: Contains the absolute path to the folder in which the current model is located
var.name: model_path

var.doc: Contains the absolute path to the workspace of GAMA
var.name: workspace_path

var.doc: Contains the absolute path to the project in which the current model is located
var.name: project_path

skill.name: moving
skill.description: The moving skill is intended to define the minimal set of behaviours required from an agent that is able to move

var.doc: the speed of the agent (in meter/second)
var.name: speed

var.doc: the absolute heading of the agent in degrees (in the range 0-359)
var.name: heading

var.doc: continuously updated destination of the agent with respect to its speed and heading (read-only)
var.name: destination

facet.doc: The agent or agents that are bound to be captured
facet.name: target
